FL-Market: Trading Private Models in Federated Learning

Shuyuan Zheng1, Yang Cao2✉, Masatoshi Yoshikawa1, Huizhong Li3, Qiang Yan4 1Kyoto University, 2Hokkaido University, 3WeBank Co., Ltd., 4Singapore Management University
Email: 1{caryzheng@db.soc., yoshikawa@}i.kyoto-u.ac.jp, 2yang@ist.hokudai.ac.jp,
3wheatli@webank.com, 4qiang.yan.2008@smu.edu.sg
Abstract

Acquiring a sufficient amount of training data is a significant bottleneck for machine learning (ML) based data analytics. Recently, commoditizing ML models has been proposed as an economical and moderate solution to ML-oriented data acquisition. However, existing model marketplaces assume that the broker can access data owners’ private training data, which may not be realistic in practice. In this paper, to promote trustworthy data acquisition for ML tasks, we propose FL-Market, a locally private model marketplace that protects privacy against not only model buyers but also an untrusted broker. FL-Market decouples ML from the need to centrally gather training data on the broker’s side using federated learning, a privacy-preserving ML paradigm in which data owners collaboratively train an ML model by uploading local gradients (to be aggregated into a global gradient for model updating). Then, FL-Market enables data owners to locally perturb their gradients by local differential privacy and thus further prevents privacy risks. To drive FL-Market, we propose a deep learning-empowered auction mechanism for intelligently deciding the local gradients’ perturbation levels and an optimal aggregation mechanism for aggregating the perturbed gradients. Our auction and aggregation mechanisms can jointly maximize the global gradient’s accuracy, which optimizes model buyers’ utility. Our experiments verify the effectiveness of the proposed mechanisms.

Index Terms:
data trading, incentive mechanism, federated learning, local differential privacy

I Introduction

Machine learning (ML) based data analytics has demonstrated great success in many domains. Acquiring a sufficient amount of private data to train ML models usually needs considerable expenses, especially as data owners are becoming increasingly aware of the value of their data and the severe risks from uncontrolled data usage after sharing the data. Consequently, recent efforts have proposed model marketplaces [1, 2, 3, 4, 5] where a data broker commercializes data owners’ private data in the form of ML models to facilitate ML-oriented data acquisition. Since model buyers do not contact training data directly, this category of business models can relieve data owners’ concerns about losing control over their data and thus incentivize data sharing to some extent.

However, data owners still face notable privacy risks in the existing model marketplaces, which may make them hesitate to contribute data. Although some works (e.g., [1, 4, 5]) reduce privacy leakage to model buyers by injecting random noise into ML models using central differential privacy (CDP) [6], existing works assume that the broker is trusted and authorized to access and control the raw data. This assumption is unrealistic, considering that many giant companies have been involved in user data breaches or privacy scandals. Therefore, we demand a model marketplace that protects privacy against not only model buyers but also its broker.

Federated learning (FL) [7] has emerged as a promising paradigm for privacy-preserving ML. Unlike traditional ML that requires training data to be stored on a centralized server (e.g., a broker in a model marketplace), FL enables the clients (i.e., data owners) to collaboratively train a model by uploading local updates (e.g., gradients) and, meanwhile, to keep their own training data on the local sides. Since FL decouples ML from the need to centrally gather training data, it can largely restrict an untrusted server’s ability to acquire private information. Even though the local gradients trained on the raw data can be sensitive [8], many works [9, 10, 11, 12, 13] suggest that local differential privacy (LDP) [14] can be combined with FL to perturb the gradients on the local sides and thus protect privacy.

In this paper, for the first time, we propose a locally private model marketplace empowered by FL and LDP, called FL-Market (Federated Learning Based Locally Private Model Market), to promote trustworthy data acquisition for ML-based data analytics. Figure 1 depicts the three parties in FL-Market: data owners, model buyers, and an FL broker. The FL broker coordinates FL-based model training and trading between data owners and model buyers. A model buyer attempts to purchase ML models with a financial budget. Data owners do not sell their raw data; instead, they sell locally private gradients perturbed by LDP in the training process coordinated by the FL broker. The perturbation level is controlled by a privacy parameter ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon, which LDP formally defines as a metric of privacy loss. To incentivize contribution, we follow seminal differentially private data marketplaces [15, 16, 17, 18, 19, 20] to employ an auction-based method for pricing gradients. Concretely, we allow each owner to report (bid) her valuation of privacy loss, named privacy valuation, and report the maximum tolerable privacy loss, called privacy budget. Then, the broker uses an auction mechanism to decide each owner’s privacy parameter and compensate for the corresponding privacy loss according to her privacy valuation. The auction should guarantee truthfulness, which means each data owner (i.e., a bidder) will never obtain a higher utility by reporting an untruthful privacy valuation and budget. Finally, the perturbed local gradients are aggregated into a global gradient by an aggregation mechanism to update the buyer’s model.

Building this model marketplace calls for an elaborate mechanism design that enables the auction and aggregation mechanisms to jointly optimize the global gradient’s utility. First, in FL-Market, the broker has to aggregate the locally private gradients considering their various accuracy levels. Consequently, the aggregation mechanism should factor in the privacy losses decided by the auction mechanism when making a decision. Second, the auction mechanism should properly purchase local gradients to maximize the aggregated gradient’s utility, which implies that the aggregation decision feeds back into the auction decision. However, the aggregation mechanism may fail to provide an analytical solution. In this case, the utility-maximizing objective of our auction problem also cannot be expressed in an analytic form, which makes it extremely challenging to characterize and design an optimal truthful mechanism. In a nutshell, the need for joint optimization dramatically increases the complexity of optimal mechanism design.

Our main contributions are threefold.

  • •

    We design a novel privacy-preserving model trading framework, FL-Market, for acquiring locally private ML models via FL (Section III). In FL-Market, data owners maintain control of their raw data by FL and enjoy the desired level of privacy against both the broker and model buyers using LDP. To the best of our knowledge, FL-Market is the first locally private model marketplace. On the other end, we formulate optimization problems for designing the auction and aggregation mechanisms with the objective of maximizing the global gradient’s accuracy, which optimizes model buyers’ utility.

  • •

    We propose an optimal aggregation mechanism OptAggr for FL with personalized LDP parameters (Section IV). The conventional practice of FL aggregates gradients with weights proportional to clients’ data sizes (i.e., all samples are uniformly weighted), which may not be optimal when the gradients are perturbed to different extents. We transform the problem of designing an optimal aggregation mechanism under personalized privacy losses into an equivalent quadratic programming problem. We prove that the equivalent problem is convex and thus can be solved by off-the-shelf optimizers. Supported by the optimizers, OptAggr decides the optimal way to aggregate the gradients.

  • •

    We propose a novel auction mechanism, DM-RegretNet, to incentivize data owners to contribute accurate gradients (Section V). Concretely, to design an optimal mechanism that jointly optimizes the gradient’s utility with the aggregation mechanism, we seek support from RegretNet, the state-of-the-art deep learning-empowered automated mechanism design technique [21]. However, RegretNet always generates randomized allocation results for auction items (i.e., the privacy losses in our case), which makes it tough to maximize the global gradient’s accuracy. On the contrary, DM-RegretNet (Deterministic Multi-Unit RegretNet) yields deterministic auction decisions jointly with OptAggr and thus can significantly improve the global gradient’s utility. Our extensive experiments demonstrate that DM-RegretNet can achieve better model accuracy and approximate the truthfulness constraint more closely than RegretNet.

II Preliminary

Federated learning

FL is a privacy-preserving framework for collaborative ML. In a typical FL architecture, n𝑛n data owners {1,…,n}1…𝑛\{1,...,n\} collaboratively train an ML model hw​(⋅)subscriptℎ𝑤⋅h_{w}(\cdot) using their datasets {D1,…,Dn}subscript𝐷1…subscript𝐷𝑛\{D_{1},...,D_{n}\} under the coordination of an FL server (e.g., the FL broker in FL-Market), where w𝑤w is a set of model parameters. The training process consists of multiple training rounds 1,…,R1…𝑅1,...,R. We show a training round r∈[R]𝑟delimited-[]𝑅r\in[R] of the widely-used FedSGD algorithm [7] as follows.

  1. 1.

    Model broadcasting: The server broadcasts model parameters wrsuperscript𝑤𝑟w^{r} with a loss function l​(⋅)𝑙⋅l(\cdot).

  2. 2.

    Local training: Each data owner i𝑖i computes a local gradient gisubscript𝑔𝑖g_{i} using her local dataset Di=[ri,j]j∈[di]subscript𝐷𝑖subscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝑟𝑖𝑗𝑗delimited-[]subscript𝑑𝑖D_{i}=[r_{i,j}]_{j\in[d_{i}]} consisting of disubscript𝑑𝑖d_{i} records. The gradient gisubscript𝑔𝑖g_{i} is the mean gradient of the records, i.e., gi=𝔼r∈Di​[∇l​(wr;r)]subscript𝑔𝑖subscript𝔼𝑟subscript𝐷𝑖delimited-[]∇𝑙superscript𝑤𝑟𝑟g_{i}=\mathbb{E}_{r\in D_{i}}[\nabla l(w^{r};r)].

Local differential privacy

LDP [14] is a de facto data privacy definition. In FL, even if data owners maintain their datasets on the local sides, their private information still can be inferred from the uploaded gradients by the server [8]. To prevent privacy leakage, data owners can use an LDP perturbation mechanism ℳℳ\mathcal{M}, such as the Laplace mechanism [6], to perturb the gradients before uploading them, which ensures that any change to the mechanism’s input does not significantly affect the output. The protection level of LDP for owner i𝑖i is parameterized by ϵisubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖\epsilon_{i}, which also quantifies her privacy loss. A smaller ϵisubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖\epsilon_{i} corresponds to a higher protection level and a more randomized perturbation. We let ℳϵisubscriptℳsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖\mathcal{M}_{\epsilon_{i}} denote a perturbation mechanism that satisfies ϵisubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖\epsilon_{i}-LDP. Note that if we perturb a gradient gisubscript𝑔𝑖g_{i} by ℳϵisubscriptℳsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖\mathcal{M}_{\epsilon_{i}}, releasing the perturbed gradient also satisfies ϵisubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖\epsilon_{i}-LDP for each record r∈Di𝑟subscript𝐷𝑖r\in D_{i}.

Definition 1 (ϵisubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖\epsilon_{i}-Local Differential Privacy [14]).

Given a privacy loss ϵi≥0subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖0\epsilon_{i}\geq 0, a randomized mechanism ℳℳ\mathcal{M} satisfies ϵisubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖\epsilon_{i}-LDP if for any two inputs x,x′∈D​o​m​a​i​n​(ℳ)𝑥superscript𝑥′𝐷𝑜𝑚𝑎𝑖𝑛ℳx,x^{\prime}\in Domain(\mathcal{M}) and any output o∈R​a​n​g​e​(ℳ)𝑜𝑅𝑎𝑛𝑔𝑒ℳo\in Range(\mathcal{M}), we have:

P​r​[ℳ​(x)=o]≤exp⁡(ϵi)⋅P​r​[ℳ​(x′)=o]𝑃𝑟delimited-[]ℳ𝑥𝑜⋅subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖𝑃𝑟delimited-[]ℳsuperscript𝑥′𝑜Pr[\mathcal{M}(x)=o]\leq\exp{(\epsilon_{i})}\cdot Pr[\mathcal{M}(x^{\prime})=o]

III FL-Market Framework

III-A Market Setup

Participants

As shown in Figure 2, there are three parties in FL-Market: data owners, model buyers, and an FL broker. A model buyer enters FL-Market to purchase a global gradient with a financial budget B𝐵B at each FL training round r𝑟r to train her target model hwrsubscriptℎsuperscript𝑤𝑟h_{w^{r}}. We assume that the buyer already knows that data owners’ data attributes meet her needs. Data owners 𝒩={1,…,n}𝒩1…𝑛\mathcal{N}=\{1,...,n\} possess local datasets D={D1,…,Dn}𝐷subscript𝐷1…subscript𝐷𝑛D=\{D_{1},...,D_{n}\} that can be used to compute local gradients g1,…,gnsubscript𝑔1…subscript𝑔𝑛g_{1},...,g_{n} for training hwrsubscriptℎsuperscript𝑤𝑟h_{w^{r}}. To prevent privacy leakage against the FL broker and model buyers, each owner i𝑖i perturbs her local gradient gisubscript𝑔𝑖g_{i} using a perturbation mechanism ℳϵisubscriptℳsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖\mathcal{M}_{\epsilon_{i}} that satisfies ϵisubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖\epsilon_{i}-LDP. The broker mediates between the model buyer and data owners in the FL process: it arranges the training tasks among data owners, collects their perturbed local gradients, and aggregates them into a perturbed global gradient for the buyer. In addition, the broker sets the payments p1,…,pnsubscript𝑝1…subscript𝑝𝑛p_{1},...,p_{n} to data owners within the buyer’s budget B𝐵B.

Privacy valuation

Inspired by [15, 16], FL-Market requires data owners to report their privacy valuations to price perturbed gradients. Concretely, each owner i𝑖i has a valuation function vi​(ϵi,di)subscript𝑣𝑖subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖subscript𝑑𝑖v_{i}(\epsilon_{i},d_{i}) that reflects her valuation of her privacy loss ϵisubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖\epsilon_{i} for her disubscript𝑑𝑖d_{i}-sized dataset: she will accept a privacy loss ϵisubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖\epsilon_{i} for disubscript𝑑𝑖d_{i} records if she obtains a payment pi≥vi​(ϵi,di)subscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝑣𝑖subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖subscript𝑑𝑖p_{i}\geq v_{i}(\epsilon_{i},d_{i}). However, in [15, 16], data owners cannot set the upper bounds of their privacy losses. To provide better privacy protection as an incentive, we follow Zheng et al. [24] to allow each owner i𝑖i to set a privacy budget ϵ¯isubscript¯italic-ϵ𝑖\bar{\epsilon}_{i} that denotes the maximum tolerable privacy loss. In practice, the broker can provide some instructions to help data owners decide privacy valuations and budgets, e.g., questionnaires for figuring out privacy preferences, typical choices for different preferences, and some analysis of historical transaction data.

Threat model

We assume that all the participants are honest-but-curious, which means they will not deviate from the protocol but will attempt to learn information from received messages. Note that in an auction, reporting a fake bid that does not represent the bidder’s real preference is not a malicious behavior that violates the protocol since the auction allows bidders to submit arbitrary bids.

III-B Trading Framework

We depict the trading framework in Fig. 2 and Alg. 1. Initially, a model buyer enters FL-Market and specifies a target model hw​(⋅)subscriptℎ𝑤⋅h_{w}(\cdot) with a loss function l​(⋅)𝑙⋅l(\cdot) for FL. Then, in each FL training round r𝑟r, the buyer purchases a global gradient for model updating by the following steps:

  1. 1.

    Auction announcement: The buyer asks the FL broker to announce a procurement auction (where bidders are sellers) for purchasing gradients, specifying a financial budget B𝐵B and model parameters wrsuperscript𝑤𝑟w^{r}.

  2. 2.

    Bidding: Data owners report their bids b1′,…,bn′superscriptsubscript𝑏1′…superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑛′b_{1}^{\prime},...,b_{n}^{\prime} in the auction. We assume that each owner i𝑖i has a real bid bi=(vi,ϵ¯i,d¯i)subscript𝑏𝑖subscript𝑣𝑖subscript¯italic-ϵ𝑖subscript¯𝑑𝑖b_{i}=(v_{i},\bar{\epsilon}_{i},\bar{d}_{i}) in mind consisting of her valuation function visubscript𝑣𝑖v_{i}, the maximum privacy budget ϵ¯isubscript¯italic-ϵ𝑖\bar{\epsilon}_{i}, and the maximum size of her dataset d¯isubscript¯𝑑𝑖\bar{d}_{i}. Then, each i𝑖i reports to the broker a valuation function vi′superscriptsubscript𝑣𝑖′v_{i}^{\prime}, a privacy budget ϵ¯i′superscriptsubscript¯italic-ϵ𝑖′\bar{\epsilon}_{i}^{\prime} and a data size disubscript𝑑𝑖d_{i} as a reported bid bi′=(vi′,ϵ¯i′,di)superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑖′superscriptsubscript𝑣𝑖′superscriptsubscript¯italic-ϵ𝑖′subscript𝑑𝑖b_{i}^{\prime}=(v_{i}^{\prime},\bar{\epsilon}_{i}^{\prime},d_{i}). If the reported bid bi′superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑖′b_{i}^{\prime} is truthful, then bi′=bisuperscriptsubscript𝑏𝑖′subscript𝑏𝑖b_{i}^{\prime}=b_{i}; otherwise, it is a fake bid, i.e., bi′≠bisuperscriptsubscript𝑏𝑖′subscript𝑏𝑖b_{i}^{\prime}\neq b_{i}. We simplify ”reported bid” as ”bid” and denote the collection of all the bids as a bid profile 𝒃′=[b1′,…,bn′]superscript𝒃′superscriptsubscript𝑏1′…superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑛′\boldsymbol{b}^{\prime}=[b_{1}^{\prime},...,b_{n}^{\prime}].

  3. 3.

    Auction decision: The broker runs an auction mechanism Auc to decide data owners’ privacy losses and payments. Formally, an auction mechanism given a bid profile 𝒃′superscript𝒃′\boldsymbol{b}^{\prime} and a financial budget B𝐵B yields an allocation of privacy losses ϵ=[ϵ1,…,ϵn]bold-italic-ϵsubscriptitalic-ϵ1…subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑛\boldsymbol{\epsilon}=[\epsilon_{1},...,\epsilon_{n}] and payments 𝒑=[p1,…,pn]𝒑subscript𝑝1…subscript𝑝𝑛\boldsymbol{p}=[p_{1},...,p_{n}].

  4. 4.

    Local gradient computing: Given model parameters wrsuperscript𝑤𝑟w^{r}, each data owner i𝑖i computes and submits a noisy gradient g~i=ℳϵi​(gi)subscript~𝑔𝑖subscriptℳsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖subscript𝑔𝑖\tilde{g}_{i}=\mathcal{M}_{\epsilon_{i}}(g_{i}) to the broker.

  5. 5.

    Gradients aggregation and model delivery: The FL broker runs an aggregation mechanism Aggr to aggregate those noisy gradients into a perturbed global gradient g~𝝀subscript~𝑔𝝀\tilde{g}_{{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}}. Finally, the broker returns g~𝝀subscript~𝑔𝝀\tilde{g}_{{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}} to the model buyer.

Gradients aggregation

In step (5), the broker needs a “good” strategy to aggregate the collected noisy gradients. To study the optimality of the aggregation mechanism in our setting, we generalize the problem as follows. Formally, given data owners’ perturbed gradients g~1,…,g~nsubscript~𝑔1…subscript~𝑔𝑛\tilde{g}_{1},...,\tilde{g}_{n}, the broker sets the aggregation weights 𝝀=[λ1,…,λn]𝝀subscript𝜆1…subscript𝜆𝑛{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}=[{\lambda}_{1},...,{\lambda}_{n}] with ∑i=1nλi=1,λi≥0,∀iformulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝜆𝑖1subscript𝜆𝑖0for-all𝑖\sum_{i=1}^{n}{\lambda}_{i}=1,{\lambda}_{i}\geq 0,\forall i and then computes the perturbed global gradient as:

g~𝝀=∑i=1nλi⋅g~i.subscript~𝑔𝝀superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛⋅subscript𝜆𝑖subscript~𝑔𝑖\tilde{g}_{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}=\sum_{i=1}^{n}{\lambda}_{i}\cdot\tilde{g}_{i}. (2)

We note that Equation (2) is a generalization of the weighted aggregation [25, 7] in the literature. Then, we attempt to design an optimal aggregation mechanism under personalized privacy losses. Specifically, we define the aggregation mechanism as a function Aggr:R2​n→Rn:Aggr→superscript𝑅2𝑛superscript𝑅𝑛\textsf{Aggr}:R^{2n}\!\rightarrow\!R^{n} that given privacy losses ϵ=[ϵ1,…,ϵn]bold-italic-ϵsubscriptitalic-ϵ1…subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑛\boldsymbol{\epsilon}\!=\![\epsilon_{1},...,\epsilon_{n}] and data sizes 𝒅=[d1,…,dn]𝒅subscript𝑑1…subscript𝑑𝑛\boldsymbol{d}\!=\![d_{1},...,d_{n}] outputs aggregation weights 𝝀=[λ1,…,λn]𝝀subscript𝜆1…subscript𝜆𝑛{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}\!=\![{\lambda}_{1},...,{\lambda}_{n}] for weighted aggregation.

III-C Mechanism Design

In this section, we formulate the problems of designing the auction mechanism Auc and aggregation mechanism Aggr (Lines 555 and 777 in Alg. 1, respectively) to instantiate the trading protocol of FL-Market. The mechanism design should achieve the following two goals: (1) to provide utility-optimal global gradients and (2) to prevent untruthful privacy valuations.

Aggregation mechanism

The aggregation mechanism should optimally aggregate perturbed local gradients to provide highly usable global gradients for model buyers. Concretely, given local gradients g~1,…,g~nsubscript~𝑔1…subscript~𝑔𝑛\tilde{g}_{1},...,\tilde{g}_{n} with privacy losses ϵbold-italic-ϵ\boldsymbol{\epsilon} and data sizes 𝒅𝒅\boldsymbol{d}, Aggr should yield optimal aggregation weights that minimize the error of the global gradient:

min𝝀⁡e​r​r​(g~𝝀;ϵ,𝒅)=‖g~𝝀−g∗‖2=‖∑i=1nλi⋅ℳϵi​(gi)−g∗‖2subscript𝝀𝑒𝑟𝑟subscript~𝑔𝝀bold-italic-ϵ𝒅subscriptnormsubscript~𝑔𝝀superscript𝑔2subscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛⋅subscript𝜆𝑖subscriptℳsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖subscript𝑔𝑖superscript𝑔2\min_{{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}}err(\tilde{g}_{{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}};\boldsymbol{\epsilon},\boldsymbol{d})=||\tilde{g}_{{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}}-g^{*}||_{2}=||\sum_{i=1}^{n}{\lambda}_{i}\cdot\mathcal{M}_{\epsilon_{i}}(g_{i})-g^{*}||_{2}

where g∗=∑i=1ndi∑j=1ndj​gisuperscript𝑔superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑑𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑛subscript𝑑𝑗subscript𝑔𝑖g^{*}=\sum_{i=1}^{n}\frac{d_{i}}{\sum_{j=1}^{n}d_{j}}g_{i} is the raw global gradient without any perturbation. The lower the error e​r​r​(g~𝝀)𝑒𝑟𝑟subscript~𝑔𝝀err(\tilde{g}_{{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}}) is, the smaller the difference between g~𝝀subscript~𝑔𝝀\tilde{g}_{{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}} and g∗superscript𝑔g^{*}, which also implies that the buyer will obtain a more accurate global model.

However, the broker cannot calculate the ground-truth error e​r​r​(g~𝝀)𝑒𝑟𝑟subscript~𝑔𝝀err(\tilde{g}_{{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}}) under LDP without the access to g1,..,gng_{1},..,g_{n}. Hence, we turn to the error bound E​R​R​(g~𝝀)𝐸𝑅𝑅subscript~𝑔𝝀ERR(\tilde{g}_{{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}}) and design the aggregation mechanism by solving the following problem:

Problem 1 (Error Bound-Minimizing Aggregation).

Auction mechanism

Solving Problem 1 alone is still insufficient to determine a utility-optimal global gradient since the utility is also affected by the privacy losses purchased for perturbing the local gradients. That is, the auction mechanism Auc should take the aggregation mechanism into account to jointly optimize the (expected) error bound of the global gradient over all possible bid profiles and financial budgets:

minϵ,𝒑=Auc​(𝒃′,B)⁡𝔼(𝒃′,B)​[E​R​R​(g~𝝀;𝝀=Aggr​(ϵ,𝒅))]subscriptbold-italic-ϵ𝒑Aucsuperscript𝒃′𝐵subscript𝔼superscript𝒃′𝐵delimited-[]𝐸𝑅𝑅subscript~𝑔𝝀𝝀Aggrbold-italic-ϵ𝒅\displaystyle\min_{\boldsymbol{\epsilon},\boldsymbol{p}=\textsf{Auc}(\boldsymbol{b}^{\prime},B)}\mathbb{E}_{(\boldsymbol{b}^{\prime},B)}[ERR(\tilde{g}_{{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}};{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}=\textsf{Aggr}(\boldsymbol{\epsilon},\boldsymbol{d}))]
=\displaystyle= 𝔼(𝒃′,B)​[supg1,…,gn‖∑i=1nλi⋅ℳϵi​(gi)−g∗‖2]subscript𝔼superscript𝒃′𝐵delimited-[]subscriptsupremumsubscript𝑔1…subscript𝑔𝑛subscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛⋅subscript𝜆𝑖subscriptℳsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖subscript𝑔𝑖superscript𝑔2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}_{(\boldsymbol{b}^{\prime},B)}[\sup_{g_{1},...,g_{n}}||\sum_{i=1}^{n}{\lambda}_{i}\cdot\mathcal{M}_{\epsilon_{i}}(g_{i})-g^{*}||_{2}]
=\displaystyle= 𝔼(𝒃′,B)​[supg1,…,gn‖Aggr​(ϵ,𝒅)⋅[ℳϵ1​(g1),…,ℳϵn​(gn)]−g∗‖2]subscript𝔼superscript𝒃′𝐵delimited-[]subscriptsupremumsubscript𝑔1…subscript𝑔𝑛subscriptnorm⋅Aggrbold-italic-ϵ𝒅subscriptℳsubscriptitalic-ϵ1subscript𝑔1…subscriptℳsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑛subscript𝑔𝑛superscript𝑔2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}_{(\boldsymbol{b}^{\prime},B)}[\sup_{g_{1},...,g_{n}}||\textsf{Aggr}(\boldsymbol{\epsilon},\boldsymbol{d})\cdot[\mathcal{M}_{\epsilon_{1}}(g_{1}),...,\mathcal{M}_{\epsilon_{n}}(g_{n})]-g^{*}||_{2}]

Then, Auc needs to determine appropriate auction results that prevent untruthful privacy valuations. Concretely, by trading a global gradient, each data owner i𝑖i obtains a utility

ui​(bi′;𝒃−i′,B)={pi−vi​(ϵi,di),ϵi≤ϵ¯i,di≤d¯i−∞,otherwisesubscript𝑢𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑖′superscriptsubscript𝒃𝑖′𝐵casessubscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝑣𝑖subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖subscript𝑑𝑖formulae-sequencesubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖subscript¯italic-ϵ𝑖subscript𝑑𝑖subscript¯𝑑𝑖otherwiseu_{i}(b_{i}^{\prime};\boldsymbol{b}_{-i}^{\prime},B)=\begin{cases}p_{i}-v_{i}(\epsilon_{i},d_{i}),&\epsilon_{i}\leq\bar{\epsilon}_{i},d_{i}\leq\bar{d}_{i}\\ -\infty,&\text{otherwise}\end{cases}

where 𝒃−i′=(b1′,…,bi−1′,bi+1′,…,bn′)superscriptsubscript𝒃𝑖′superscriptsubscript𝑏1′…superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑖1′superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑖1′…superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑛′\boldsymbol{b}_{-i}^{\prime}=(b_{1}^{\prime},...,b_{i-1}^{\prime},b_{i+1}^{\prime},...,b_{n}^{\prime}) denotes the other bidders’ bids. Then, Auc should ensure the following incentives:

  • •

    Truthfulness: With the other bidders’ bids 𝒃−i′superscriptsubscript𝒃𝑖′\boldsymbol{b}_{-i}^{\prime} fixed, each bidder i𝑖i never obtains a higher utility by reporting a fake bid bi′≠bisuperscriptsubscript𝑏𝑖′subscript𝑏𝑖b_{i}^{\prime}\neq b_{i}, i.e., ∀i,∀bi′,∀B,ui​(bi′;𝒃−i′,B)≤ui​(bi;𝒃−i′,B)for-all𝑖for-allsuperscriptsubscript𝑏𝑖′for-all𝐵subscript𝑢𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑖′superscriptsubscript𝒃𝑖′𝐵subscript𝑢𝑖subscript𝑏𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒃𝑖′𝐵\forall i,\forall b_{i}^{\prime},\forall B,u_{i}(b_{i}^{\prime};\boldsymbol{b}_{-i}^{\prime},B)\leq u_{i}(b_{i};\boldsymbol{b}_{-i}^{\prime},B).

  • •

    Individual rationality (IR): Each bidder i𝑖i never obtains a negative utility, i.e., ui​(bi′)≥0,∀bi′,∀isubscript𝑢𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑖′0for-allsuperscriptsubscript𝑏𝑖′for-all𝑖u_{i}(b_{i}^{\prime})\geq 0,\forall b_{i}^{\prime},\forall i.

  • •

    Budget feasibility (BF): The payments should be within the financial budget, i.e., ∑ipi≤Bsubscript𝑖subscript𝑝𝑖𝐵\sum_{i}p_{i}\leq B.

Therefore, we can design the auction mechanism by solving the following problem.

Problem 2 (Budget-Limited Multi-Unit Multi-Item Procurement Auction).
minϵ,𝒑=Auc​(𝒃′,B)⁡𝔼(𝒃′,B)​[E​R​R​(g~𝝀;𝝀=Aggr​(ϵ,𝒅))]subscriptbold-italic-ϵ𝒑Aucsuperscript𝒃′𝐵subscript𝔼superscript𝒃′𝐵delimited-[]𝐸𝑅𝑅subscript~𝑔𝝀𝝀Aggrbold-italic-ϵ𝒅\displaystyle\min_{\boldsymbol{\epsilon},\boldsymbol{p}=\textsf{Auc}(\boldsymbol{b}^{\prime},B)}\mathbb{E}_{(\boldsymbol{b}^{\prime},B)}[ERR(\tilde{g}_{{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}};{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}=\textsf{Aggr}(\boldsymbol{\epsilon},\boldsymbol{d}))]
S.t.: ∀i,ϵi∈[0,ϵ¯i′], truthfulness, IR, and BF.formulae-sequencefor-all𝑖subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖0subscriptsuperscript¯italic-ϵ′𝑖 truthfulness, IR, and BF.\displaystyle\forall i,\epsilon_{i}\in[0,\bar{\epsilon}^{\prime}_{i}],\text{ truthfulness, IR, and BF.}

Problem 2 is a budget-limited multi-unit multi-item procurement auction problem [26] because (1) each data owner’s privacy loss ϵisubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖\epsilon_{i} can be seen as a divisible item for procurement with ϵ¯i′subscriptsuperscript¯italic-ϵ′𝑖\bar{\epsilon}^{\prime}_{i} units available, and (2) the buyer purchases privacy losses under her financial budget B𝐵B. To the best of our knowledge, such a problem has yet to be generally solved in the literature. Moreover, we have to involve the aggregation mechanism in minimizing the global gradient’s error bound, which increases the complexity of optimal mechanism design. Concretely, the privacy losses affect the aggregation weights in Problem 1, but the latter also feeds back into the former in Problem 2, which calls for joint optimization. By solving this problem, we can obtain an auction mechanism that maximizes the global gradient’s utility jointly with Aggr.

Computational efficiency

We additionally require that the auction and aggregation mechanisms (designed by solving Problems 1 and 2) should finish in polynomial time, which ensures the efficiency of FL-Market. Note that we design the mechanisms offline before executing Algorithm 1 rather than during each FL training round therein.

IV Aggregation Mechanism: OptAggr

In this section, we propose an error-optimal aggregation mechanism OptAggr by solving a convex quadratic programming problem that we prove is equivalent to Problem 1.

Error bound decomposition

It is well known that the MSE error of a random variable consists of its variance and squared bias. Let σisubscript𝜎𝑖\sigma_{i} denote the variance of the local gradient g~isubscript~𝑔𝑖\tilde{g}_{i}, and let Wi=di∑j∈[n]dj,∀isubscript𝑊𝑖subscript𝑑𝑖subscript𝑗delimited-[]𝑛subscript𝑑𝑗for-all𝑖W_{i}=\frac{d_{i}}{\sum_{j\in[n]}d_{j}},\forall i. Problem transformation

We further transform Problem 1 into a convex quadratic programming problem. First, to minimize the error bound, any data owner i𝑖i with ϵi=0subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖0\epsilon_{i}=0 must be allocated a zero-valued weight λi=0subscript𝜆𝑖0{\lambda}_{i}=0 by an optimal solver because its gradient g~isubscript~𝑔𝑖\tilde{g}_{i} has an infinite variance σisubscript𝜎𝑖\sigma_{i}. For simplicity, we assume that only the first k≤n𝑘𝑛k\leq n data owners have positive privacy losses without loss of generality. Then, we let 𝒙=[λ1,…,λk]𝒙subscript𝜆1…subscript𝜆𝑘\boldsymbol{x}=[{\lambda}_{1},...,{\lambda}_{k}] and replace the terms |λi−Wi|,∀i∈[k]subscript𝜆𝑖subscript𝑊𝑖for-all𝑖delimited-[]𝑘|{\lambda}_{i}-W_{i}|,\forall i\in[k] with auxiliary variables 𝒚=[y1,…,yk]𝒚subscript𝑦1…subscript𝑦𝑘\boldsymbol{y}=[y_{1},...,y_{k}] with the constraints yi≥−(λi−Wi),yi≥λi−Wi,∀i∈[k]formulae-sequencesubscript𝑦𝑖subscript𝜆𝑖subscript𝑊𝑖formulae-sequencesubscript𝑦𝑖subscript𝜆𝑖subscript𝑊𝑖for-all𝑖delimited-[]𝑘y_{i}\geq-({\lambda}_{i}-W_{i}),y_{i}\geq{\lambda}_{i}-W_{i},\forall i\in[k]. Consequently, we have the following quadratic programming problem [27].

Problem 3 (Equivalent problem of Problem 1).
min𝒙,𝒚⁡12​[𝒙𝒚]T​[D​i​a​g​([σ1,…,σk])00U​n​i​(L2)k×k]​[𝒙𝒚]subscript𝒙𝒚12superscriptmatrix𝒙𝒚𝑇matrix𝐷𝑖𝑎𝑔subscript𝜎1…subscript𝜎𝑘00𝑈𝑛𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝐿2𝑘𝑘matrix𝒙𝒚\displaystyle\min_{\boldsymbol{x},\boldsymbol{y}}\frac{1}{2}\begin{bmatrix}\boldsymbol{x}\\ \boldsymbol{y}\end{bmatrix}^{T}\begin{bmatrix}Diag([\sigma_{1},...,\sigma_{k}])&0\\ 0&Uni(L^{2})_{k\times k}\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}\boldsymbol{x}\\ \boldsymbol{y}\end{bmatrix}

where 𝐈ksubscript𝐈𝑘\boldsymbol{I}_{k} is a k×k𝑘𝑘k\times k identity matrix, U​n​i​(a)m×n𝑈𝑛𝑖subscript𝑎𝑚𝑛Uni(a)_{m\times n} is an m×n𝑚𝑛m\times n matrix where all the elements are equal to a∈R𝑎𝑅a\in R, D​i​a​g​([σ1,…,σk])𝐷𝑖𝑎𝑔subscript𝜎1…subscript𝜎𝑘Diag([\sigma_{1},...,\sigma_{k}]) is a k×k𝑘𝑘k\times k diagonal matrix with D​i​a​g​([σ1,…,σk])​[i]​[i]=σi,∀i∈[k]formulae-sequence𝐷𝑖𝑎𝑔subscript𝜎1…subscript𝜎𝑘delimited-[]𝑖delimited-[]𝑖subscript𝜎𝑖for-all𝑖delimited-[]𝑘Diag([\sigma_{1},...,\sigma_{k}])[i][i]\!=\!\sigma_{i},\forall i\in[k], and 𝐖=[W1,…,Wk]𝐖subscript𝑊1…subscript𝑊𝑘\boldsymbol{W}\!=\![{W}_{1},...,{W}_{k}].

Because Problem 3 is a convex quadratic programming problem, it can be well solved by many existing solvers in polynomial time, e.g., the SCS solver [28] to be used in our experiments. Note that there is no existing analytical solution to Problem 3 to the best of our knowledge. Hence, we propose the OptAggr mechanism that (1) allocates zero-valued aggregation weights to those data owners with zero-valued privacy losses and (2) then computes other data owners’ aggregation weights by solving Problem 3 with a polynomial-time optimizer, as depicted in Algorithm 2.

Proposition 1.

Problem 3 is a convex quadratic programming problem and is equivalent to Problem 1.

Proof.

Let 𝒬=\medmath​[D​i​a​g​([σ1,…,σk])00U​n​i​(L2)k×k]𝒬\medmathmatrix𝐷𝑖𝑎𝑔subscript𝜎1…subscript𝜎𝑘00𝑈𝑛𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝐿2𝑘𝑘\mathcal{Q}=\medmath{\begin{bmatrix}Diag([\sigma_{1},...,\sigma_{k}])&0\\ 0&Uni(L^{2})_{k\times k}\end{bmatrix}} and A=\medmath​[D​i​a​g​([σ1,…,σk])00U​n​i​(Lk)k×k]𝐴\medmathmatrix𝐷𝑖𝑎𝑔subscript𝜎1…subscript𝜎𝑘00𝑈𝑛𝑖subscript𝐿𝑘𝑘𝑘A=\medmath{\begin{bmatrix}Diag([\sqrt{\sigma_{1}},...,\sqrt{\sigma_{k}}])&0\\ 0&Uni(\frac{L}{\sqrt{k}})_{k\times k}\end{bmatrix}}. Because 𝒬=AT​A𝒬superscript𝐴𝑇𝐴\mathcal{Q}=A^{T}A, 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q} is a positive semidefinite matrix. Therefore, Problem 3 is a convex quadratic programming problem.

For each yisubscript𝑦𝑖y_{i}, a solver for Problem 3 will find the lowest value of yisubscript𝑦𝑖y_{i} as possible. Therefore, if λi−Wi≥0subscript𝜆𝑖subscript𝑊𝑖0{\lambda}_{i}-W_{i}\geq 0, the constraint yi≥λi−Wisubscript𝑦𝑖subscript𝜆𝑖subscript𝑊𝑖y_{i}\geq{\lambda}_{i}-W_{i} is equivalent to yi=λi−Wisubscript𝑦𝑖subscript𝜆𝑖subscript𝑊𝑖y_{i}={\lambda}_{i}-W_{i} and implies yi≥−(λi−Wi)subscript𝑦𝑖subscript𝜆𝑖subscript𝑊𝑖y_{i}\geq-({\lambda}_{i}-W_{i}); if λi−Wi≤0subscript𝜆𝑖subscript𝑊𝑖0{\lambda}_{i}-W_{i}\leq 0, the constraint yi≥−(λi−Wi)subscript𝑦𝑖subscript𝜆𝑖subscript𝑊𝑖y_{i}\geq-({\lambda}_{i}-W_{i}) is equivalent to yi=−(λi−Wi)subscript𝑦𝑖subscript𝜆𝑖subscript𝑊𝑖y_{i}=-({\lambda}_{i}-W_{i}) and implies yi≥λi−Wisubscript𝑦𝑖subscript𝜆𝑖subscript𝑊𝑖y_{i}\geq{\lambda}_{i}-W_{i}. Therefore, the constraints yi≥λi−Wisubscript𝑦𝑖subscript𝜆𝑖subscript𝑊𝑖y_{i}\geq{\lambda}_{i}-W_{i} and yi≥−(λi−Wi)subscript𝑦𝑖subscript𝜆𝑖subscript𝑊𝑖y_{i}\geq-({\lambda}_{i}-W_{i}) are equivalent to yi=|λi−Wi|subscript𝑦𝑖subscript𝜆𝑖subscript𝑊𝑖y_{i}=|{\lambda}_{i}-W_{i}|. Therefore, we conclude that Problem 3 is equivalent to Problem 1. ∎

V Auction Mechanism: DM-RegretNet

In this section, we design a truthful mechanism that maximizes the global gradient’s utility jointly with the OptAggr mechanism. Since OptAggr does not provide an analytical solution to Problem 3, the objective function also cannot be expressed in an analytic form, which makes it extremely difficult to characterize and design an optimal truthful mechanism. To design a truthful mechanism that optimizes the nonanalytical objective, we turn to an automated mechanism design approach that achieves an auction objective by ML. We also propose a traditional auction mechanism in Appendix B.

RegretNet

We seek support from RegretNet [21], the state-of-the-art automated mechanism design framework for multi-item auctions. As depicted in Figure 5, RegretNet consists of two deep learning networks: an allocation network and a payment network. Both the networks take as input data owners’ bid profile 𝒃′superscript𝒃′\boldsymbol{b}^{\prime} and the buyer’s financial budget B𝐵B but output allocation probabilities zi∈(0,1),∀isubscript𝑧𝑖01for-all𝑖z_{i}\in(0,1),\forall i and payments p1,…,pnsubscript𝑝1…subscript𝑝𝑛p_{1},...,p_{n}, respectively. Therefore, RegretNet is a randomized auction mechanism: the allocation result of each data owner’s privacy loss is a binary random variable ϵisubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖\epsilon_{i} with P​r​[ϵi=ϵ¯i′]=zi𝑃𝑟delimited-[]subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖subscriptsuperscript¯italic-ϵ′𝑖subscript𝑧𝑖Pr[\epsilon_{i}=\bar{\epsilon}^{\prime}_{i}]=z_{i} and P​r​[ϵi=0]=1−zi𝑃𝑟delimited-[]subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖01subscript𝑧𝑖Pr[\epsilon_{i}=0]=1-z_{i}.111The concrete privacy loss ϵisubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖\epsilon_{i} to be used to perturb the local gradient is a sample of the random variable. To reduce notational overload, we use ϵisubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖\epsilon_{i} to denote the random variable in Section V. Then, the truthfulness constraint is approximately guaranteed by model training: the violation degree of truthfulness is quantified as a regret penalty in the training objective function to be minimized.

Problems with RegretNet

RegretNet may perform poorly in our auction problem. First, RegretNet can only auction single-unit items and output binary auction results. That is, under RegretNet, the allocation result of each data owner i𝑖i’s privacy loss (i.e., the item ϵisubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖\epsilon_{i}) is either to purchase the whole unit (i.e., ϵi=ϵ¯i′subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖subscriptsuperscript¯italic-ϵ′𝑖\epsilon_{i}=\bar{\epsilon}^{\prime}_{i}) or not to purchase any privacy loss (i.e., ϵi=0subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖0\epsilon_{i}=0). However, we should support trading a portion of the privacy budget ϵ¯i′subscriptsuperscript¯italic-ϵ′𝑖\bar{\epsilon}^{\prime}_{i} to flexibly optimize the global gradient’s utility. Second, some extra variance from the randomness of the allocation results by RegretNet might be introduced into the perturbed local gradients. Third, also because of the allocation randomness, RegretNet cannot treat the (expected) error bound minimization function as the objective function for model training. Intuitively, RegretNet always allocates zero-valued privacy losses for all data owners with probability P​r​[ϵ1=…=ϵn=0]=∏i=1n(1−zi)𝑃𝑟delimited-[]subscriptitalic-ϵ1…subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑛0superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑖1𝑛1subscript𝑧𝑖Pr[\epsilon_{1}=...=\epsilon_{n}=0]=\prod_{i=1}^{n}(1-z_{i}), which means that the expected error bound of the perturbed global gradient g~𝝀subscript~𝑔𝝀\tilde{g}_{{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}} remains infinite and cannot be minimized.

M-RegretNet

To solve the first problem with RegretNet, we extend the allocation network of RegretNet and propose M-RegretNet (Multi-Unit RegretNet). As shown in Figure 4, like RegretNet, M-RegretNet has an allocation (payment) network with multiple fully connected hidden layers, each of which has multiple hidden nodes with tanh activations. However, it does not take the reported bids as input. Instead, for each data owner i𝑖i, we transform her reported bid bi′=(vi′,ϵ¯i′,di)superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑖′superscriptsubscript𝑣𝑖′superscriptsubscript¯italic-ϵ𝑖′subscript𝑑𝑖b_{i}^{\prime}=(v_{i}^{\prime},\bar{\epsilon}_{i}^{\prime},d_{i}) into M𝑀M sub-bids bi|1′,…,bi|M′superscriptsubscript𝑏conditional𝑖1′…superscriptsubscript𝑏conditional𝑖𝑀′b_{i|1}^{\prime},...,b_{i|M}^{\prime} and then input them into M-RegretNet, where bi|m′=(vi′​(m⋅ϵ¯i′M,di),m⋅ϵ¯i′M,di),∀m∈[M]formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑏conditional𝑖𝑚′superscriptsubscript𝑣𝑖′⋅𝑚superscriptsubscript¯italic-ϵ𝑖′𝑀subscript𝑑𝑖⋅𝑚superscriptsubscript¯italic-ϵ𝑖′𝑀subscript𝑑𝑖for-all𝑚delimited-[]𝑀b_{i|m}^{\prime}=(v_{i}^{\prime}(\frac{m\cdot\bar{\epsilon}_{i}^{\prime}}{M},d_{i}),\frac{m\cdot\bar{\epsilon}_{i}^{\prime}}{M},d_{i}),\forall m\in[M]. Regarding the payment network, it first generates budget fractions p¯0,…,p¯nsubscript¯𝑝0…subscript¯𝑝𝑛\bar{p}_{0},...,\bar{p}_{n} and then output payments pi=p¯i⋅B,∀i∈[n]formulae-sequencesubscript𝑝𝑖⋅subscript¯𝑝𝑖𝐵for-all𝑖delimited-[]𝑛p_{i}=\bar{p}_{i}\cdot B,\forall i\in[n]. Because the budget fractions are output by a softmax activation function, the sum of the payments ∑i∈[n]pisubscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛subscript𝑝𝑖\sum_{i\in[n]}p_{i} never exceeds the financial budget B𝐵B, which ensures BF. Then, the allocation network outputs 𝒛i=[zi​0,zi​1,…,zi​M]subscript𝒛𝑖subscript𝑧𝑖0subscript𝑧𝑖1…subscript𝑧𝑖𝑀\boldsymbol{z}_{i}=[z_{i0},z_{i1},...,z_{iM}] for each data owner i𝑖i, where zi​0subscript𝑧𝑖0z_{i0} denotes the probability of data owner i𝑖i losing the auction, and zi​msubscript𝑧𝑖𝑚z_{im} is the probability of data owner i𝑖i winning with her sub-bid bi|m′superscriptsubscript𝑏conditional𝑖𝑚′b_{i|m}^{\prime}. Since each owner i𝑖i should win with at most one sub-bid, we apply softmax activation functions to ensure that ∑m=0Mzi​m=1,∀isuperscriptsubscript𝑚0𝑀subscript𝑧𝑖𝑚1for-all𝑖\sum_{m=0}^{M}z_{im}=1,\forall i. Therefore, the allocation result for each data owner i𝑖i is a random variable ϵisubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖\epsilon_{i} with M+1𝑀1M+1 possible values, i.e., P​r​[ϵi=m⋅ϵ¯i′M]=zi​m,∀m∈{0,1,…,M}formulae-sequence𝑃𝑟delimited-[]subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖⋅𝑚superscriptsubscript¯italic-ϵ𝑖′𝑀subscript𝑧𝑖𝑚for-all𝑚01…𝑀Pr[\epsilon_{i}=\frac{m\cdot\bar{\epsilon}_{i}^{\prime}}{M}]=z_{im},\forall m\in\{0,1,...,M\}. When M=1𝑀1M=1, M-RegretNet reduces to a budget-feasible version of RegretNet; when M≥2𝑀2M\geq 2, it enables the buyer to only purchase a part of each data owner’s privacy budget. In addition, when M𝑀M increases, it becomes easier for M-RegretNet to approximate the truthfulness and IR guarantees since it has more possible values to allocate as privacy losses.

DM-RegretNet

To address the second and third problems with RegretNet, we further propose DM-RegretNet that outputs deterministic allocation results. DM-RegretNet deploys M-RegretNet as a module to determine allocation probabilities 𝒛1,…,𝒛nsubscript𝒛1…subscript𝒛𝑛\boldsymbol{z}_{1},...,\boldsymbol{z}_{n} and payments p1,…,pnsubscript𝑝1…subscript𝑝𝑛p_{1},...,p_{n}. Then, it realizes deterministic allocation results by processing the vector of allocation probabilities 𝒛i=[zi​0,…,zi​M]subscript𝒛𝑖subscript𝑧𝑖0…subscript𝑧𝑖𝑀\boldsymbol{z}_{i}=[z_{i0},...,z_{iM}] into a one-hot vector; by such a process, there is only one one-valued allocation probability for each data owner i𝑖i, and thus each privacy loss ϵisubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖\epsilon_{i} is deterministic. Formally, it is

ϵi=\medmath​[0,1⋅ϵ¯i′M,…,M⋅ϵ¯i′M]⋅o​n​e​_​h​o​t​(a​r​g​m​a​x​(𝒛i))subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖⋅\medmath0⋅1superscriptsubscript¯italic-ϵ𝑖′𝑀…⋅𝑀superscriptsubscript¯italic-ϵ𝑖′𝑀𝑜𝑛𝑒_ℎ𝑜𝑡𝑎𝑟𝑔𝑚𝑎𝑥subscript𝒛𝑖\epsilon_{i}=\medmath{[0,\frac{1\cdot\bar{\epsilon}_{i}^{\prime}}{M},...,\frac{M\cdot\bar{\epsilon}_{i}^{\prime}}{M}]\cdot one\_hot({argmax}(\boldsymbol{z}_{i}))} (3)

where o​n​e​_​h​o​t​(⋅)𝑜𝑛𝑒_ℎ𝑜𝑡⋅one\_hot(\cdot) is a function that takes as input an integer m∈[0,M]𝑚0𝑀m\in[0,M] and outputs an (M+1)𝑀1(M+1)-length one-hot vector where the m𝑚m-th element equals 111 and the others are zero-valued. However, the function o​n​e​_​h​o​t​(a​r​g​m​a​x​(⋅))𝑜𝑛𝑒_ℎ𝑜𝑡𝑎𝑟𝑔𝑚𝑎𝑥⋅one\_hot(argmax(\cdot)) is nondifferentiable, which makes the networks untrainable.

To realize deterministic allocation results while ensuring trainable networks, we apply the soft argmax trick [29] to DM-RegretNet. Then, as shown in Alg. 3, for the model inference phase, DM-RegretNet obtains deterministic allocation results by Equation (3); for the model training phase, it uses the following differentiable estimator to approximate Equation (3):

ϵ^i=[0,1⋅ϵ¯i′M,…,M⋅ϵ¯i′M]⋅s​o​f​t​m​a​x​(𝒛𝒊/τ)subscript^italic-ϵ𝑖⋅0⋅1superscriptsubscript¯italic-ϵ𝑖′𝑀…⋅𝑀superscriptsubscript¯italic-ϵ𝑖′𝑀𝑠𝑜𝑓𝑡𝑚𝑎𝑥subscript𝒛𝒊𝜏\hat{\epsilon}_{i}=[0,\frac{1\cdot\bar{\epsilon}_{i}^{\prime}}{M},...,\frac{M\cdot\bar{\epsilon}_{i}^{\prime}}{M}]\cdot{softmax}(\boldsymbol{z_{i}}/\tau)

where τ𝜏\tau is a smoothing parameter that controls the tradeoff between the estimator’s approximation accuracy and smoothness. If we use a smaller τ𝜏\tau, the estimator ϵ^isubscript^italic-ϵ𝑖\hat{\epsilon}_{i} will approach the truth but become harder to optimize.

Then, to further promote the approximation accuracy, we introduce the deterministic allocation constraint when training DM-RegretNet, which requires that s​o​f​t​m​a​x​(𝒛𝒊/τ)𝑠𝑜𝑓𝑡𝑚𝑎𝑥subscript𝒛𝒊𝜏{softmax}(\boldsymbol{z_{i}}/\tau) should be a one-hot vector. Consider a vector 𝒛U=[z0U,…,zMU]superscript𝒛𝑈subscriptsuperscript𝑧𝑈0…subscriptsuperscript𝑧𝑈𝑀\boldsymbol{z}^{U}=[z^{U}_{0},...,z^{U}_{M}] with uniform allocation probabilities, i.e., zmU=1M+1,∀m∈[0,M]formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscript𝑧𝑈𝑚1𝑀1for-all𝑚0𝑀{z}^{U}_{m}=\frac{1}{M+1},\forall m\in[0,M]. Obviously, for a vector 𝒛=[z0,…,zM]𝒛subscript𝑧0…subscript𝑧𝑀\boldsymbol{z}=[z_{0},...,z_{M}] of allocation probabilities, the squared Euclidean distance between 𝒛𝒛\boldsymbol{z} and 𝒛Usuperscript𝒛𝑈\boldsymbol{z}^{U} is maximized only when 𝒛𝒛\boldsymbol{z} is a one-hot vector:

\medmath​sup𝒛∑m∈[0,M](zm−zmU)2=(1−1M+1)2+M​(0−1M+1)2=MM+1\medmathsubscriptsupremum𝒛subscript𝑚0𝑀superscriptsubscript𝑧𝑚subscriptsuperscript𝑧𝑈𝑚2superscript11𝑀12𝑀superscript01𝑀12𝑀𝑀1\displaystyle\medmath{\sup_{\boldsymbol{z}}\sum_{m\in[0,M]}(z_{m}-z^{U}_{m})^{2}=(1-\frac{1}{M+1})^{2}+M(0-\frac{1}{M+1})^{2}=\frac{M}{M+1}}

Then, we formalize the deterministic allocation constraint over the vector 𝒛i′=[zi​0′,…,zi​M′]=s​o​f​t​m​a​x​(𝒛𝒊/τ)superscriptsubscript𝒛𝑖′superscriptsubscript𝑧𝑖0′…superscriptsubscript𝑧𝑖𝑀′𝑠𝑜𝑓𝑡𝑚𝑎𝑥subscript𝒛𝒊𝜏\boldsymbol{z}_{i}^{\prime}=[z_{i0}^{\prime},...,z_{iM}^{\prime}]={softmax}(\boldsymbol{z_{i}}/\tau) as:

d​a​vi​(θ)=𝔼(𝒃,B)​[MM+1−∑m∈[0,M](zi​m′−zmU)2]=0.𝑑𝑎subscript𝑣𝑖𝜃subscript𝔼𝒃𝐵delimited-[]𝑀𝑀1subscript𝑚0𝑀superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑧𝑖𝑚′subscriptsuperscript𝑧𝑈𝑚20{dav}_{i}(\theta)=\mathbb{E}_{(\boldsymbol{b},B)}[\frac{M}{M+1}-\sum_{m\in[0,M]}(z_{im}^{\prime}-z^{U}_{m})^{2}]=0.

where θ𝜃\theta is the network parameters of DM-RegretNet. We note that 𝒛i′superscriptsubscript𝒛𝑖′\boldsymbol{z}_{i}^{\prime} is determined by the network parameters θ𝜃\theta and the input (b,B)𝑏𝐵(b,B) to DM-RegretNet.

Training DM-RegretNet

We train DM-RegretNet by solving Problem 2. Concretely, given a (real) bid profile 𝒃𝒃\boldsymbol{b} and a financial budget B𝐵B, we can obtain a global gradient:

g~𝝀,θ=Aggr​(ϵ^,𝒅)⋅[ℳϵ^1​(g1),…,ℳϵ^n​(gn)]subscript~𝑔𝝀𝜃⋅Aggrbold-^bold-italic-ϵ𝒅subscriptℳsubscript^italic-ϵ1subscript𝑔1…subscriptℳsubscript^italic-ϵ𝑛subscript𝑔𝑛\tilde{g}_{{\boldsymbol{\lambda}},\theta}=\textsf{Aggr}(\boldsymbol{\hat{\epsilon}},\boldsymbol{d})\cdot[\mathcal{M}_{\hat{\epsilon}_{1}}(g_{1}),...,\mathcal{M}_{\hat{\epsilon}_{n}}(g_{n})]

where the estimated privacy losses ϵ^=[ϵ^1,…,ϵ^n]bold-^bold-italic-ϵsubscript^italic-ϵ1…subscript^italic-ϵ𝑛\boldsymbol{\hat{\epsilon}}=[\hat{\epsilon}_{1},...,\hat{\epsilon}_{n}] are affected by the network parameters θ𝜃\theta. The training objective thus is to find the optimal network parameters that minimize the expected error bound 𝔼(𝒃,B)​[E​R​R​(g~𝝀,θ;𝝀=Aggr​(ϵ^,𝒅))]subscript𝔼𝒃𝐵delimited-[]𝐸𝑅𝑅subscript~𝑔𝝀𝜃𝝀Aggrbold-^bold-italic-ϵ𝒅\mathbb{E}_{(\boldsymbol{b},B)}[ERR(\tilde{g}_{{\boldsymbol{\lambda}},\theta};{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}=\textsf{Aggr}(\boldsymbol{\hat{\epsilon}},\boldsymbol{d}))].

Then, we relax the truthfulness constraint and quantify the violation degree of truthfulness for data owner i𝑖i by the expected regret (normalized by the expected valuation of her allocated privacy loss ciθ​(bi;𝒃−i,B)=∑m=1Mzi​m′⋅vi​(m⋅ϵ¯iM,d¯i)superscriptsubscript𝑐𝑖𝜃subscript𝑏𝑖subscript𝒃𝑖𝐵superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀⋅superscriptsubscript𝑧𝑖𝑚′subscript𝑣𝑖⋅𝑚subscript¯italic-ϵ𝑖𝑀subscript¯𝑑𝑖c_{i}^{\theta}(b_{i};\boldsymbol{b}_{-i},B)=\sum_{m=1}^{M}z_{im}^{\prime}\cdot v_{i}(\frac{m\cdot\bar{\epsilon}_{i}}{M},\bar{d}_{i}) under parameters θ𝜃\theta):

r​g​ti​(θ)=𝔼(𝒃,B)​[max⁡(0,maxbi′⁡uiθ​(bi′;𝒃−i,B)−uiθ​(bi;𝒃−i,B))ciθ​(bi;𝒃−i,B)]𝑟𝑔subscript𝑡𝑖𝜃subscript𝔼𝒃𝐵delimited-[]0subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑏𝑖′superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝜃superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑖′subscript𝒃𝑖𝐵superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝜃subscript𝑏𝑖subscript𝒃𝑖𝐵superscriptsubscript𝑐𝑖𝜃subscript𝑏𝑖subscript𝒃𝑖𝐵{rgt}_{i}(\theta)=\mathbb{E}_{(\boldsymbol{b},B)}[\frac{\max(0,\max_{b_{i}^{\prime}}u_{i}^{\theta}(b_{i}^{\prime};\boldsymbol{b}_{-i},B)-u_{i}^{\theta}(b_{i};\boldsymbol{b}_{-i},B))}{c_{i}^{\theta}(b_{i};\boldsymbol{b}_{-i},B)}]

where uiθsuperscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝜃u_{i}^{\theta} is data owner i𝑖i’s utility function under network parameters θ𝜃\theta. Similarly, the violation degree of the IR constraint can be measured by the expected IR violation:

i​r​vi​(θ)=𝔼(𝒃,B)​[m​a​x​(0,−uiθ​(bi;𝒃−i,B))ciθ​(bi;𝒃−i,B)]𝑖𝑟subscript𝑣𝑖𝜃subscript𝔼𝒃𝐵delimited-[]𝑚𝑎𝑥0superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝜃subscript𝑏𝑖subscript𝒃𝑖𝐵superscriptsubscript𝑐𝑖𝜃subscript𝑏𝑖subscript𝒃𝑖𝐵{irv}_{i}(\theta)=\mathbb{E}_{(\boldsymbol{b},B)}[\frac{max(0,-u_{i}^{\theta}(b_{i};\boldsymbol{b}_{-i},B))}{c_{i}^{\theta}(b_{i};\boldsymbol{b}_{-i},B)}]

Therefore, we have the following optimization problem.

Problem 4 (DM-RegretNet Training Problem).
minθ⁡𝔼(𝒃,B)​[E​R​R​(g~𝝀,θ;𝝀=Aggr​(ϵ^,𝒅))]subscript𝜃subscript𝔼𝒃𝐵delimited-[]𝐸𝑅𝑅subscript~𝑔𝝀𝜃𝝀Aggrbold-^bold-italic-ϵ𝒅\displaystyle\min_{\theta}\mathbb{E}_{(\boldsymbol{b},B)}[ERR(\tilde{g}_{{\boldsymbol{\lambda}},\theta};{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}=\textsf{Aggr}(\boldsymbol{\hat{\epsilon}},\boldsymbol{d}))]
S.t.: r​g​ti​(θ)=0,∀i(Truthfulness)𝑟𝑔subscript𝑡𝑖𝜃0for-all𝑖(Truthfulness)\displaystyle{rgt}_{i}(\theta)=0,\forall i\quad\text{(Truthfulness)}
i​r​vi​(θ)=0,∀i(Individual Rationality)𝑖𝑟subscript𝑣𝑖𝜃0for-all𝑖(Individual Rationality)\displaystyle{irv}_{i}(\theta)=0,\forall i\quad\text{(Individual Rationality)}
d​a​vi​(θ)=0,∀i(Deterministic Allocation)𝑑𝑎subscript𝑣𝑖𝜃0for-all𝑖(Deterministic Allocation)\displaystyle{dav}_{i}(\theta)=0,\forall i\quad\text{(Deterministic Allocation)}

We can empirically estimate the expected error bound and those violation degrees from some training data and solve an empirical version of Problem 4 to train DM-RegretNet. The details can be checked in Appendix A. The training data can be drawn from a known distribution or historical data. Note that DM-RegretNet is trained offline before the execution of Algorithm 1; in each FL training round, the trained auction model makes a model inference to decide the auction result, which efficiently finishes in polynomial time.

VI Evaluation

VI-A Setup

Research questions

We investigate the following research questions through experiments.

  • •

    RQ1: How does the proposed auction mechanism DM-RegretNet perform compared with the baselines (explained below) in terms of minimizing the error bound?

  • •

    RQ2: Can OptAggr outperform the conventional aggregation method in FL?

  • •

    RQ3: How does DM-RegretNet approximately guarantee the truthfulness and IR constraints?

  • •

    RQ4: Does increasing M𝑀M benefit approximating the truthfulness and IR guarantees?

Baselines

We compare OptAggr with the conventional aggregation method ConvlAggr [7], which allocates positive aggregation weights only to those data owners with nonzero privacy losses, and the weights are proportional to their data sizes. Regarding auction, we compare DM-RegretNet with RegretNet [21] and M-RegretNet.222Our code, data, and trained models are available at https://github.com/teijyogen/FL-Market. We use the CVXPY [30] and cvxpylayers [31] libraries to implement the OptAggr aggregation mechanism.

FL settings

We use real data to train FL models. We choose logistic regression classifiers as FL models and use the NSL-KDD [32] datasets for 555-class classification with 125973125973125973 training samples and 225442254422544 test samples. We distribute the training samples among 100010001000 data owners to form their local datasets using the following partition methods:

  • •

    IID: We follow [33] to draw all the local datasets from the same distribution, and their sizes follow a power law.

  • •

    Non-IID: We follow [34] to allocate each class of samples among clients according to the Dirichlet distribution.

We set the learning rate η=0.01𝜂0.01\eta=0.01 and the threshold L=1.0𝐿1.0L=1.0 for gradient clipping and perturb local gradients by the Laplace mechanism [6].

Auction settings

For each run of the experiment, we simulate 100100100 rounds of FL and generate 100010001000 data owners; in each round, we randomly select 101010 data owners as bidders in the auction. To simulate various types of bids, we let each bidder randomly select a basic valuation function from four provided: a linear function vL​(ϵi,di)=2⋅di⋅ϵisuperscript𝑣𝐿subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖subscript𝑑𝑖⋅2subscript𝑑𝑖subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖v^{L}(\epsilon_{i},d_{i})=2\cdot d_{i}\cdot\epsilon_{i}, a quadratic function vQ​(ϵi,di)=di⋅(ϵi)2superscript𝑣𝑄subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖subscript𝑑𝑖⋅subscript𝑑𝑖superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖2v^{Q}(\epsilon_{i},d_{i})=d_{i}\cdot(\epsilon_{i})^{2}, a square-root function vS​(ϵi,di)=2⋅di⋅ϵisuperscript𝑣𝑆subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖subscript𝑑𝑖⋅2subscript𝑑𝑖subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖v^{S}(\epsilon_{i},d_{i})=2\cdot d_{i}\cdot\sqrt{\epsilon_{i}}, and an exponential function vE​(ϵi,di)=di⋅(exp⁡(ϵi)−1)superscript𝑣𝐸subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖subscript𝑑𝑖⋅subscript𝑑𝑖subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖1v^{E}(\epsilon_{i},d_{i})=d_{i}\cdot(\exp(\epsilon_{i})-1), which are natural choices considered in [16]; these functions are directly proportional to the data size disubscript𝑑𝑖d_{i} because it is natural to model the valuation of a dataset as the sum of the valuations of the data records therein. Then, we consider each owner’s valuation function to be a randomly selected rate α∈[0.5,1.5]𝛼0.51.5\alpha\in[0.5,1.5] of the selected function, e.g., vi​(ϵi,di)=α⋅vL​(ϵi,di)subscript𝑣𝑖subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖subscript𝑑𝑖⋅𝛼superscript𝑣𝐿subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖subscript𝑑𝑖v_{i}(\epsilon_{i},d_{i})=\alpha\cdot v^{L}(\epsilon_{i},d_{i}). Finally, we randomly generate each data owner’s privacy budget ϵ¯i∈[0.5,2.0]subscript¯italic-ϵ𝑖0.52.0\bar{\epsilon}_{i}\in[0.5,2.0], which is in line with those commonly used in the differential privacy research community. For DM-RegretNet and M-RegretNet, we set M=8𝑀8M=8 by default. We train all the auction models on 102,400102400102,400 bid profiles with 505050 epochs.

Evaluation metric

To evaluate the utilities of the global gradients, we use as evaluation metrics the expected empirical error bound E​R​R^^𝐸𝑅𝑅\hat{ERR}, the model accuracy (i.e., the percentage of correctly predicted examples), and the invalid gradient rate (i.e., the frequency of sampling zero-valued privacy losses for all data owners). Then, to evaluate the truthfulness and IR guarantees of the auction mechanisms, we use the empirical regret r​g​t^isubscript^𝑟𝑔𝑡𝑖\hat{rgt}_{i} and empirical IR violation i​r​v^isubscript^𝑖𝑟𝑣𝑖\hat{irv}_{i} as the metrics. The definitions of the above metrics can be found in Appendix A.

VI-B Experimental Results

Incentive mechanisms comparison (RQ1)

First, we test the auction mechanisms’ performance in minimizing the error bound. We vary the financial budget factor B¯¯𝐵\bar{B} and let the budget B=B¯⋅∑i∈[n]vi​(ϵ¯i,d¯i)𝐵⋅¯𝐵subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛subscript𝑣𝑖subscript¯italic-ϵ𝑖subscript¯𝑑𝑖B=\bar{B}\cdot\sum_{i\in[n]}v_{i}(\bar{\epsilon}_{i},\bar{d}_{i}). As shown in Figure 6(a), our DM-RegretNet can generate global gradients with a lower error bound in expectation. When the financial budget factor increases and exceeds 1.01.01.0, which means the budget covers the gross valuation of the bidders’ privacy budgets, the error bound may still be able to decrease since the payments made by a truthful auction mechanism are usually much higher than the winners’ valuations. We note that since the randomized mechanisms RegretNet and M-RegretNet may sample zero-valued privacy losses for all data owners, which results in invalid global gradients with infinite error, we only take the error bound of valid gradients into account. That means that even if Figure 6(a) shows that RegretNet results in low error bounds, it actually frequently generates invalid gradients with infinite error, while our DM-RegretNet based mechanisms never do, which is depicted in Figure 6(b). For the rest experiments, we sample the budget factor uniformly at random from [0.1,2.0]0.12.0[0.1,2.0]. We also test the model accuracy over 100100100 FL training rounds. As shown in Figure 6(c), in both cases, DM-RegretNet makes better auction decisions that result in more accurate models.

Aggregation mechanisms comparison (RQ2)

As depicted in Figure 6(a), under each auction mechanism, our OptAggr aggregation mechanism can always generate global gradients with a lower error bound in expectation than ConvlAggr. In addition, Figure 6(c) shows that model buyers can obtain more accurate models using global gradients aggregated by OptAggr. Therefore, OptAggr outperforms ConvlAggr.

Incentive guarantees (RQ3).

Table I illustrates the violation degrees of truthfulness and IR of those RegretNet-based auction mechanisms. The empirical regrets and IR violations under DM-RegretNet are significantly lower than those under RegretNet and M-RegretNet, which means that DM-RegretNet has stronger abilities to approximate the truthfulness and IR constraints. DM-RegretNet has this advantage because it is a deterministic mechanism that universally guarantees truthfulness and IR, while RegretNet and M-RegretNet are randomized mechanisms that approximate the two constraints by expectation.

Parameter effects (RQ4)

We vary the value of parameter M∈{1,2,4,8,16}𝑀124816M\in\{1,2,4,8,16\} to test its effects on the truthfulness and IR guarantees. For each value, we train 101010 instances of M-RegretNet and test them to obtain the average result. Figure 6(d) shows that under M-RegretNet, an increase in M𝑀M decreases both the regret and IR violation, which demonstrates our intuition that a larger M𝑀M can enhance the abilities of M-RegretNet to approximate the truthfulness and IR guarantees as it has more possible values to allocate as privacy losses.

VII Related Work

Incentive mechanisms for FL

Many incentive mechanisms [36, 37, 38, 39, 40, 41, 42, 43] have been proposed to encourage participation in FL by providing appropriate rewards for data owners’ contributions. The contributions can be evaluated in various ways. For example, Zhan et al. [42] consider the data size, the most basic measurement of data, for contribution evaluation. Then, from a cost-covering perspective, Jiao et al. [36] propose an auction mechanism where data owners can bid their computational and communication costs in providing their FL training services. Similarly, Sarikayar et al. [39] regard the CPU computational costs as their contributions. Then, Richardson et al. [37] evaluate data owners’ influences on the model accuracy to decide their rewards. The Shapley value is also adapted into an FL version by Wang et al. [38] to value data owners’ influence. Data quality is another natural choice. Since the data quality is known only to data owners, to ensure the contribution of high-quality data, Kang et al. [40] design different types of rewarding contracts to distinguish data owners such that the FL server can infer the data quality based on the contracts they select. In this way, the rewards are essentially determined by the data quality. In addition, both the works of Kang et al. [41] and Zhang et al. [43] employ some reputation metric to remove unreliable data owners from FL. However, none of the above mechanisms considers privacy protection, which is also a critical incentive. To fill this gap, we propose an auction-based incentive mechanism that protects data owners’ privacy and compensates them according to their privacy preferences.

FL under LDP

Some efforts [44, 9, 10, 11, 12, 45, 13, 46] have devoted to designing FL frameworks under LDP. Since the data perturbation under LDP may substantially reduce the utility of FL models, these authors mainly focus on how to reduce the perturbation level while still providing appropriate privacy guarantees. Concretely, to relieve the utility problem that the noise that LDP injects into a gradient should be proportional to its size, Liu et al. [11] propose an FL framework to perturb only the top-k important dimensions of the gradient and thus can its utility. Then, Liu et al. [12] and Girgis et al. [46] employ the shuffle model [47] in their FL frameworks to amplify the privacy guarantee under the same level of noise injection. Then, Sun et al. [10] propose a more secure LDP mechanism that can extend the difference between the perturbed data and its original value while introducing lower variance. There are also works on designing LDP-based FL frameworks for specific ML tasks [44, 9, 13]. While prior works address the utility problem under LDP by relaxing the privacy guarantee or elaborately injecting noise, we tackle it from an incentive perspective, i.e., by incentivizing data owners to contribute more privacy loss, which can also increase utility. In addition, Zhao et al. [45] propose an LDP-based FedSGD algorithm, which is similar to our protocol in privacy protection; however, they assume uniform privacy losses for all data owners and thus do not consider different perturbation levels when aggregating gradients.

VIII Conclusion and Future Work

In this paper, we propose FL-Market to facilitate trustworthy data acquisition for ML-based data analytics. Our mechanisms can incentivize data sharing by providing preferred levels of local privacy and compensation for data owners and optimizing model buyers’ utility. FL-Market opens up new possibilities for ML-oriented data acquisition and initiates a new direction toward designing locally private model marketplaces. There are several interesting future directions. One question is how to guarantee that the auction decisions are arbitrage free against strategic buyers. Another question is how to apply and optimize FL-Market in specific learning tasks.

Appendix B All-in: Single-Minded Auction Mechanism

We propose an auction mechanism All-in for single-minded data owners, each of whom has a step valuation function vi​(ϵi,di)={Vi,ϵi∈(0,ϵ¯i],di∈(0,d¯i]0,ϵi=0​ or ​di=0subscript𝑣𝑖subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖subscript𝑑𝑖casessubscript𝑉𝑖formulae-sequencesubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖0subscript¯italic-ϵ𝑖subscript𝑑𝑖0subscript¯𝑑𝑖0subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖0 or subscript𝑑𝑖0v_{i}(\epsilon_{i},d_{i})=\begin{cases}V_{i},&\epsilon_{i}\in(0,\bar{\epsilon}_{i}],d_{i}\in(0,\bar{d}_{i}]\\ 0,&\epsilon_{i}=0\text{ or }d_{i}=0\end{cases} where Vi>0subscript𝑉𝑖0V_{i}>0 is a constant set by i𝑖i. Therefore, we can use Visubscript𝑉𝑖V_{i} and Vi′superscriptsubscript𝑉𝑖′V_{i}^{\prime} to represent the real valuation visubscript𝑣𝑖v_{i} and the reported valuation vi′superscriptsubscript𝑣𝑖′v_{i}^{\prime}, respectively. Such cases are common in practice because some data owners are just willing to sell all their small datasets and privacy budgets at a single round of auction or only focus on whether their private information is leaked rather than how much is leaked. Obviously, each data owner i𝑖i can only have two kinds of auction results: (1) win the auction with ϵi=ϵ¯i′subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖superscriptsubscript¯italic-ϵ𝑖′\epsilon_{i}=\bar{\epsilon}_{i}^{\prime} or (2) lose the auction with ϵi=0subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖0\epsilon_{i}=0.

To meet the demands of single-minded bidders, we can design a truthful mechanism using Myerson’s characterization [48], which indicates that the monotonicity and critical payment properties imply truthfulness. Concretely, monotonicity requires that a winner should still win if she re-reports a higher privacy budget, a larger data size, and/or a lower valuation with other bidders’ bids fixed; the critical payment property ensures that winners are paid the maximum possible payments (i.e., critical payments) and hence that they have no incentive to misreport bids. However, the limited financial budget makes the problem more difficult because the winner selection should depend on the payments, which in turn depend on the selection results. Hence, we should carefully identify budget-feasible critical payments.

To capture the interdependency between the winner selection and payment decision, All-in takes the payments into account when selecting winners. Concretely, to guarantee monotonicity, All-in selects data owners in ascending order of their unit valuations viu​n​i​t=Vi′di⋅ϵ¯i′superscriptsubscript𝑣𝑖𝑢𝑛𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑉𝑖′⋅subscript𝑑𝑖superscriptsubscript¯italic-ϵ𝑖′v_{i}^{unit}=\frac{V_{i}^{\prime}}{d_{i}\cdot\bar{\epsilon}_{i}^{\prime}}; intuitively, if a owner i𝑖i decreases her valuation Vi′superscriptsubscript𝑉𝑖′V_{i}^{\prime}, increases her data size disubscript𝑑𝑖d_{i}, and/or increases her privacy budget ϵ¯i​’subscript¯italic-ϵ𝑖’\bar{\epsilon}_{i}’, she stays at the same position or moves to a former position in the order. Then, the winner selection procedure is to find the last owner whose unit valuation viu​n​i​tsuperscriptsubscript𝑣𝑖𝑢𝑛𝑖𝑡v_{i}^{unit} is covered by the critical unit price B∑j∈𝒲∪{i}dj⋅ϵ¯j′𝐵subscript𝑗𝒲𝑖⋅subscript𝑑𝑗superscriptsubscript¯italic-ϵ𝑗′\frac{B}{\sum_{j\in\mathcal{W}\cup\{i\}}d_{j}\cdot\bar{\epsilon}_{j}^{\prime}}. In this design, the winners’ payments that exhaust the financial budget B𝐵B are critical because if a winner i𝑖i claims a higher unit valuation viu​n​i​t′>pu​n​i​tsuperscriptsubscript𝑣𝑖𝑢𝑛𝑖superscript𝑡′superscript𝑝𝑢𝑛𝑖𝑡v_{i}^{unit^{\prime}}>p^{unit} to gain a higher payment, she definitely loses the auction due to the violation of BF. Therefore, truthfulness is ensured.

Proposition 2.

All-in satisfies truthfulness, IR, and BF.

Proof.

All-in satisfies IR because the critical unit payment pu​n​i​tsuperscript𝑝𝑢𝑛𝑖𝑡p^{unit} is no lower than each winner i𝑖i’s unit valuation viu​n​i​tsuperscriptsubscript𝑣𝑖𝑢𝑛𝑖𝑡v_{i}^{unit}. Then, we prove that All-in satisfies truthfulness. Let Vi′superscriptsubscript𝑉𝑖′V_{i}^{\prime} be the reported Visubscript𝑉𝑖V_{i}, Ui=ui​(bi;b−i′,B)subscript𝑈𝑖subscript𝑢𝑖subscript𝑏𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑖′𝐵U_{i}=u_{i}(b_{i};b_{-i}^{\prime},B) and Ui′=ui​(bi′,b−i′,B)superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑖′subscript𝑢𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑖′superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑖′𝐵U_{i}^{\prime}=u_{i}(b_{i}^{\prime},b_{-i}^{\prime},B). For each data owner i𝑖i, we should discuss four cases as follows.

  1. 1.

    ϵ¯i′>ϵ¯isuperscriptsubscript¯italic-ϵ𝑖′subscript¯italic-ϵ𝑖\bar{\epsilon}_{i}^{\prime}>\bar{\epsilon}_{i} and/or di>d¯isubscript𝑑𝑖subscript¯𝑑𝑖d_{i}>\bar{d}_{i}: Obviously, data owner i𝑖i has no incentive because Ui′=−∞superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑖′U_{i}^{\prime}=-\infty.
